summary: the 2003 SARS outbreak in East Asia, including Taiwan, and subsequent public health threat from avian influenza, MERS, and Zika outbreaks in the region, have tested Taiwan's preparedness for public health emergencies. the 2003 SARS outbreak in East Asia, including Taiwan, and the subsequent public health threat from avian influenza, MERS, and Zika outbreaks have repeatedly tested Taiwan's readiness for public health emergencies. the external evaluation process was planned to involve 2 separate visits to Taipei, Taiwan, including a pre-self-assessment orientation visit (pilot visit) in march 2016 and the evaluation mission, which took place in June 2016. three subject matter experts from the external assessment team were on the pilot visit. members of the multisectoral team were asked to submit point-by-point responses in English to the technical and contextual questions in the designated JEE element by May 16, 2016. the team was asked not to provide a self-scoring result. four high-ranking officials reviewed the reports to ensure appropriateness of the content and representativeness of the report at the national level. the external assessment team reviewed the written self-assessment report and supporting documentation, interviewed the multisectoral team members who had presented the results. each session lasting 2 hours. the key to success in achieving such large-scale multisectoral collaborations for JEE is the 10-month preparatory work beforehand. previous self-assessment and external assessment experiences in Taiwan were useful in planning and advocating for the JEE. the JEE is expected to be repeated every 4 to 5 years. the public health, animal health, and science and technology authorities have jointly proposed a 4-year project (2017-2020) with an annual budget of $7.5 million.
